comments.commentBody: Blow is now one more commentator who fails to note that objecting to invocations of Sharia law (appropriate) is contradictory to objecting to invocations of Christian Bible law (the county clerk who refuses to issues same-sex marriage licenses.) Carson and most of the other GOP candidates supported both positions!

Yet if one researches the number of Blacks, Muslims, Jews and Hispanics elected to Congress there are literally next to zero of any of these minorities, either religious or racial minorities, in the Republican Congress. There are 3 Blacks, no Muslims, no Jews and a few Hispanics. There are 47 Blacks in the Democratic House, representing a far greater percentage in Congress than their racial makeup in America which is 11%. There are 18 Jewish members also representing far more than their religious counterpart in the general population which is 2.2%. But the Republicans claim to be the inclusive party because they have a Black man and a couple of Latinos running for president. The facts prove otherwise. But who CARES about facts!

Carson and Clarence Thomas. Every group has them.
For amoral opportunists, the quickest way up is to align with the powerful even if they deal in division by race/religion. Black Repubs have a greater chance of advancement, so the Gop can pretend it’s the soul of democratic values.
Carson projects his own role model—politicians who let religion influence their policies, in a diverse democracy that prides itself on tolerance and freedom.

A feature of US politics despite our explicit 'church state separation' is religious fundamentalism, used by politicians. Religious fanatics pretend they’re being persecuted if anyone objects to the imposition of their views. The excuse is our founding ideals of ‘freedom of religion’. But this is all warped in our politics. Religious fanatics run their candidates.

European nations separate religion and politics despite having official state religions. The US has explicit church state separation in the Constitution, but our leaders must all end their speeches with god bless and show religious faith.

Referring to god is supposed to show a US politician has strong morality. It’s said no atheist could get elected here. In other countries voters don't even know what their leaders' belief system is and don't care.

They care whether or not a candidate represent the majority interests vs the special interests.
US candidates must represent special $$ interests in order to run. But they say god bless, so they’re OK.

As a white collar employee for 25 years, I have been out of work for the past 12 months.  While I can afford catastrophe coverage, I cannot afford quality health insurance for my family.  I have been avoiding health care visits as much as possible.  My deductible is $6,000 for the year.  I have multiple teeth issues and have not had a proper physical in 3 years.  Bottom line is I can't afford preventive care.  I read arguments that a free market system is best for health care but I can't see how the profit motive of insurance companies and pharmaceutical companies benefit my preventive care.
I thought the whole piece was about initiation into a rarefied and self-delighted elite class?
Did you just confirm the article's description of elite contempt for the poor?  I think you did!

As amusing as it is to see Ashcroft rain down a thousand nasty soundbites on Sad-Eyed Dave, the Lords is the real joke here. Just look at the recent list of additions. It's not entirely clear that Black-Mirroring a pig on BBC One would prevent one from joining that enoromous and useless body of fur-collared expense-accounters.

Unlike the US, there is no true democratic representative government in the UK.
The members in the House of Lords( which does have legislative power over the laws passed by the MP's in the House of Parliament) is not elected by the populace. Instead seats and titles are "given" by the sitting Prime Minister to random people such as ex MP's, business friends and is a real prize for generous party donors like the lovely Lord Ashcroft.
There are not many MP's (members of parliament) who are elected, that display much 'wisdom' never mind the pigs at the trough in the House of Lords.
With a Queen figurehead who has no real power over parliament I'm ashamed to say Britain may have the oldest democracy but by no means a true one.

I think this is a wonderful story and only makes Mr. Cameron more human.

Who I find off-putting and offensive is Lord Ashcroft.... If he can't handle rejection, he certainly does not have the wisdom and confidence to be a Lord in Parliament.

Brilliant!

Trust you are completely A'cing college! You certainly deserve to.

Right, because middle class and the poor never engage in anything disgusting in their youth.  Perhaps you need to read through the Internet pages about how the inner city boys gleefully torture and burn and/or dismember dogs and cats.

Spoiled, rich children acting like spoiled, rich children and in no way being held to account.

Earth shattering.

I think the media and twitter storm about this reflects the fact that this was too delicious a story to pass up. In addition to #piggate there is #snoutrage, #hameron and #baeofpigs (among other gags).

And yes, what makes it even more delicious is the Eton/Oxford overprivileged toff aspect, with a strong undercurrent of resentment against the Tory hubris and utter callousness in government.

This reminds me of the "beer and bingo" campaign advert for the 2015 election. "Cutting the beer tax and bingo duty to help hardworking people do more of the things they enjoy"

This was not surprisingly seen as just a bit patronising. Once people picked themselves up off the floor, they created some very hilarious parodies of the image if you google "beer and bingo".

http://www.independent.co.uk/news/uk/politics/tory-bingo-grant-shapps-br...

But not all college students have their own private police force in bowler hats, There is definitely a difference between what goes on at fraternities and other weirdly homo erotic clubs in the US and what goes on in the UK. The US pretends not to have a class system, and to a certain degree it's true. I think the author's point was not just the silliness and visually disgusting image of Mr. Cameron having sex with a pig's head, but also the fact that this behavior is institutionalized in Britain, even glorified. Members of the House of Lords literally get paid for doing nothing. And as that recent scandal showed, with Lord  whatever his name was - as he snorted cocaine in a red bra and waxed poetic about the sexuality of Asian women, he says, quite happily, that the money for the coke is coming from taxpayers. There's something rotted out about the English class system, which seems to be permanently stuck in adolescence probably because it gets a free pass from the whole country to do whatever it wants to do and do it with a kind of built-in obscenity that they are not only untouchable, but brilliant, elitist and callow. I think the author has really touched on something.

Oh give me a break. Really? How many young college students do stupid things? A heck of a lot. This goes for both those born of privilege and those not so well funded. I think if we honestly look back on our early college years, we all were guilty of doing some pretty bizarre things. Frankly, this is rather tame on the college excess scoreboard.

"no one is particularly interested in what Alf and Edna and their spotty offspring are getting up to in a council flat"

The success of Coronation Street and East Enders would suggest otherwise, even if the interested parties are only other Alfs and Ednas. But then folks on your side of the pond are interested in Uncle Billy Bob and aunt Peg (especially aunt Peg).

A simpler explanation would be that this story was already in the background and the writers of that episode used it on their show. It would not help Lord Ashcroft to sell his book if he stole an incident from a popular(?) TV show and passed it off as a saucy anecdote about the PM.
For the British ruling class, old chap? Never, never, never, dear boy!

It's ridiculous to characterize the UK as enthralled in the 80s with the parasitic class by citing "Brideshead Revisited.

After all, this was the decade that also brought us Billy Bragg's "Levi Stubbs' Tears," one of the greatest pop songs ever written and definitely NOT about the parasitic class.

I can't help but feel how prescient the British dystopian series Black Mirror was (and is).  The first episode wrestled with the British PM being publicly forced to have "carnal knowledge" of a pig in order to save a kidnapped princess.  So much of the episode wrestled with the public devouring the shame of others--disgusted by the thought of such an act, but unable to turn away from the public humiliation.  As the PM wrestles with the extent of the ransom demand, one of his advisors tells him that the public has already seen the encounter in their head. I hate that those stupid, elite boys could entertain themselves with such depravity.  I'm more weary of being bombarded by those being publicly humiliated.  I don't want these images in my head.  All we're going to do is become more and more desensitized. Then more horrible and graphic images will be thrown at us to get our attention.

"Something silly", you say? My that little word could hardly encompass such an act. I could think of a thousand things that college boys do that never come close to such gross behavior.

When I went off to college, I briefly considered fraternities. I would not have lasted, because, first off, I would not have engaged in initiation rights of any sort. I would not have submitted to the orders of others to humiliate myself in a way that might be pleasing to them, of this I am certain, because I refused to participate in the ordinary traditions of harassment to which freshmen were then subjected. The price of joining such clubs, and feeling that one was part of a larger group, a pal in crime as it were, was too high.

Excellent point! Who among us, ensconced in the upper echelons of inherited wealth, hasn't greedily feasted upon the carcass of a freshly slaughtered orphan? Has no one any respect for tradition these days?
@Andrew: Did you do stuff like this? Do you know anybody who did? You seem to imply that it happens all the time, no big deal, not weird.

What a stupid piece of news.  Who in Uk or America who were part of an eating club or a fraternity didn't do something silly as part of initiation rights.  All the pots calling the kettle black are.....
For all we know it is a regular occurrence and something that Dave has always enjoyed with his posh mates. You doth protest too much.
The  statute of limitations applies if a law was broken.   One is not protected if someone simply squeals about a previous event.
I agree. The only difference is that he probably wasn't yelling "DUDE!" or "BRAH!" while doing it

It was a one time event; an initiation ceremony at a university. No one was in the least bit harmed. Strange? Maybe - but such events are common practice all over the world.
And this practice doesn't appear to have involved hazing; a far more seroius rite of passage.
I thought the same thing. It got really condescending in the last paragraph.
This is the best thing I've read in NYT in a long time. Love it!

So good.  I broke the cauliflower into florets to make browning easier, skipped the anchovies (can't stand them), used much more wine (bottle needed finishing, it wasn't nice enough to drink), used jalapeños (as I had them on hand), added some salty black olives and threw in a can of butter beans towards the end.  Sprinkled with chopped parsley before serving.  Delicious.
I, for one, would be very happy to see a Muslim POTUS.

Carson is suffering from Great Man Syndrome - which is what happens when a person of great accomplishment in one field assumes that competence extends to all fields. Combine that with authoritarian tendencies and a sense of entitlement, and the result is not pretty.
